sms.subject: null
sms.body: Yo, so is arc consistency for a constraint graph when you are able to make the graph so that everything works right. So for the example he gave us in class with the R,G,B graph when their where no nodes connected that shared the same color that was arc consistent.

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Hey Jack, so arc consistency pertains to a pair of nodes or states having a valid domain to each other. Note that if we make a graph arc consistent and the result is an empty domain then the problem is unsolvable. Thus, in the RGB graph, we ensured arc consistency by comparing two adjacent states and making sure they were bound to their domains and satisfied the constraints. So yes, arc consistency ensured that no two adjacent nodes had the same color.

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Hey man, the information gain I got for the split on humidity was 0.048

sms.subject: null
sms.body:
Entropy(Target, Humidity) = P(Humidity ≤75) * Entropy(4/5, 1/5) + P(Humidity >75) * Entropy(5/9, 4/9)
Information Gain = Entropy(Target) – Entropy(Target, Humidity)

sms.subject: null
sms.body: That is weird. I got -.063. I must have accidentally added .1 somewhere

sms.subject: null
sms.body: I hate when that happens. Check out this video if you need help figuring out entropy and information gain. It's pretty much a walk-through of this homework assignment but with slightly different attribute values: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O__7lAqni7A

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Are you factoring in the probability of playing and the probability of not playing?

sms.subject: null
sms.body: So, for example when I was doing the info gain on outlook I was doing the entropy of the outlook - the weighted sum of the entropy of the class(play/not play) for each type of outlook.

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Also, if you do it the entropy for the overcast outlook should be zero.

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Yeah the overcast entropy is 0

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Entropy for Sunny should be 0.971 and the Entropy for Rain should also be 0.971

sms.subject: null
sms.body: I got an entropy of .971 for the other 2.

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Ya, then weighting them by multiplying them by 5/24

sms.subject: null
sms.body: To weight them.

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Then add them together. And subtract that value from 1.578

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Why are you weighting them?

sms.subject: null
sms.body: You have to

sms.subject: null
sms.body: I didn't do that

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Ohhhhhh, ya you need to do that.

sms.subject: null

sms.subject: null
sms.body: So if 1 is greater than or equal to zero it is true, but if 0 is less then 0 it is false. It has to be one since 0 always has to be zero.

sms.subject: null

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Try testing all possible combinations of x1 and x2 against the following: (x1 + w1) + (x2 + w2) <= t; if true then 0, else 1

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Hey man, for the project, what do you do once you have chosen the first split. If we were to use the decision tree homework as an example, after we choose the split on outlook because it yields the greatest information gain, what would we do next?

sms.subject: null
sms.body: You then find the best information gain for the data with each specific output. So say if you split it at sunny you find the best information gain for the data that has an outlook of sunny and then split at that data and keep going. Like a Tree. So if you split at sunny and then the best information gain for the sunny data is the humidity data you then split the sunny data at humidity.

sms.subject: null
sms.body: But raining data can be split at a different column because is it windy has a better information gain for rainy data then humidity.

sms.subject: null
sms.body: That's what I was thinking but I was getting confused. Thanks man!

sms.subject: null

Since both inputs being 1 outputs 2 it is the only value greater than 1 that can be produced in the perceptron.

sms.body: It was asking about high and low c values, i.e., high or low slack

sms.subject: null
sms.body: One you draw a hyper plane splitting the data and the other you ignore the outliers.

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Yeah so the high value c-constant gives better generalization. That's the one where you draw the maximum margin hyperplane. The low c-constant promotes accuracy.

sms.subject: null
sms.body: The higher c-constant doesn't care as much if their is a miss-classification of data (or just points that are on the wrong side of the line).

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Ya, that is what I was assuming. I just looked at the data and realized that their where 2 outliers so that kinda gave it away for me.

sms.subject: null
sms.body: Yeah fortunately there were some outliers in the dataset
